course: IB DP Mathematics: Applications and Interpretation (AI) — HL

SL.notes: SL1.1–SL1.5 are common to AA and AI

content: Operations with numbers in the form a × 10^k (1 ≤ a < 10, k ∈ ℤ).
Calculator/computer notation like 5.2E30 is not acceptable; write 5.2 × 10^30.
Arithmetic sequences and series.
Formulae for nth term and sum of first n terms.
Sigma notation for sums of arithmetic sequences.
Applications (e.g., simple interest); analysis/interpretation where data are only approximately arithmetic.
Geometric sequences and series.
Formulae for nth term and sum of first n terms.
Sigma notation for sums of geometric sequences.
Simplifying expressions with rational exponents (numeric and algebraic).
Sum of infinite geometric sequences.
Links to limits and Markov chains.
Complex numbers i with i^2 = −1.
Cartesian form z = a + bi; real/imaginary parts, conjugate, modulus, argument.
Sums, differences, products, quotients (by hand and technology); powers in Cartesian form with technology.
Argand diagram; complex roots of quadratics with negative discriminant.
Modulus–argument (polar) form z = r(cos θ + i sin θ) = r·cis θ.
Exponential form z = r e^{iθ}.
Convert between Cartesian, polar, exponential; products/quotients/powers in polar/exponential.
Adding sinusoids with same frequency but different phase.
Matrices: elements, rows, columns, order (m×n).
Equality, addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication; matrix multiplication and its properties (associative, distributive, non-commutative).
Identity and zero matrices.
Determinants/inverses of n×n with technology; by hand for 2×2.
Solve Ax = b with inverses; modelling (coding/decoding, systems of equations).
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors (2×2); characteristic polynomial.
Diagonalization (distinct real eigenvalues).
Applications to powers of matrices (e.g., population movement, predator–prey).
M^n = P D^n P^{-1} (P eigenvectors, D eigenvalues).

SL.notes: SL2.1–SL2.4 are common to AA and AI

content: Equations of a straight line; gradient, intercepts.
Parallel m1 = m2; perpendicular m1·m2 = −1.
Forms: y = mx + c; ax + by + d = 0; y − y1 = m(x − x1).
Concept of function, domain, range, graph.
Function notation f(x), v(t), C(n).
Function as model; inverse function informally (reflection in y = x); f^{-1}(x) notation; 1–1 requirement.
Graph of a function; equation y = f(x).
Distinguish ‘draw’ vs ‘sketch’. (Further detail continues in guide.)
Composite functions (f ∘ g)(x) and inverse function f^{-1}; domain restriction; identities f ∘ f^{-1}(x) = f^{-1} ∘ f(x) = x.

Transformations of graphs for all covered functions: translations y = f(x) + b, y = f(x − a); reflections y = −f(x), y = f(−x); vertical stretch y = p f(x); horizontal stretch y = f(qx); composite transformations and order.
Additional modelling functions beyond SL:
• Exponential models for half-life.
• Natural logarithmic models f(x) = a + b ln x.
• Sinusoidal models f(x) = a sin(bx − c) + d (radian default unless degree sign used); period 2π/b.
Logarithmic scaling for very large/small numbers.
Linearization with log/semilog to identify exponential vs power relationships; using best-fit lines to determine parameters.
Interpretation of log–log and semi-log plots.

SL.notes: SL3.1–SL3.3 common to AA and AI

content: Distance and midpoint in 3D.
Volume/surface area of: right pyramid, right cone, sphere, hemisphere, combinations.
Angle between two lines or a line and a plane.
Right-angled trig only for 3D in SL exams.
Sine/cosine/tangent in right triangles.
Sine rule a/sinA = b/sinB = c/sinC; cosine rule c^2 = a^2 + b^2 − 2ab cos C, cos C = (a^2 + b^2 − c^2)/(2ab).
Area of triangle ½ab sin C (no ambiguous case at SL).
Applications of right and non-right-angled trigonometry incl. Pythagoras.
Angles of elevation/depression; labelled diagram construction; bearings contexts.
Circle: arc length; sector area (radians not required at SL).
Perpendicular bisector equations (two points or line segment with midpoint).
Voronoi diagrams: sites, vertices, edges, cells; adding a site; nearest-neighbour interpolation; ‘toxic waste dump’ applications; exam conventions for boundaries/areas/closest site.
Radians: definition; degrees↔radians conversion.
Arc length and sector area in radians.
Unit-circle definitions of sin θ, cos θ; Pythagorean identity.
tan θ = sin θ / cos θ; ambiguous case of sine rule.
Graphical solution of trig equations over finite intervals.
Graph theory basics: graphs, vertices, edges; degree; simple/complete/weighted graphs; directed graphs (in-/out-degree); subgraphs; trees; represent real structures as graphs.
Adjacency matrices; number of k-length walks from entries of A^k; weighted adjacency; construct transition matrices for strongly-connected graphs; PageRank as an example.
Tree and cycle algorithms for undirected graphs.
Walks/trails/paths/circuits/cycles; Eulerian trails/circuits; Hamiltonian paths/cycles.
MST algorithms (Kruskal, Prim, matrix method for Prim).
Chinese postman problem (shortest route around weighted graph with up to four odd vertices) and justification of algorithm choice.
Travelling Salesman Problem (TSP): nearest-neighbour (upper bound), deleted-vertex (lower bound); reduce practical cases to classical form.

SL.notes: SL4.1–SL4.9 common to AA and AI (plus SL4.10–SL4.11 specific tests)

content: Population, sample, random sample; discrete/continuous data; reliability/bias; handling missing/erroneous data.
Venn/tree/sample-space/tables of outcomes to compute probabilities.
Combined events P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B); mutually exclusive events; conditional probability P(A|B)=P(A∩B)/P(B); independent events P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B); with/without replacement.
Discrete random variables and distributions.
Expected value E[X] for discrete data; recognition of ‘fair’ games; probability-distribution specification formats.
Binomial distribution; mean and variance; appropriateness conditions; find probabilities using technology.
Normal distribution and curve; empirical 68–95–99.7 rule.
Normal probability and inverse-normal calculations using technology (no z-standardization required).
Hypotheses H0 and H1; significance levels; p-values.
χ² test of independence (contingency tables, df, critical values) and χ² goodness-of-fit (exam conventions).
t-test (two means, one- or two-tailed; use technology); express hypotheses properly; compare p-values or χ² to critical values.
Confidence intervals for mean of normal population.
Use normal (σ known) or t (σ unknown) regardless of n; interpret in context.
Poisson distribution (mean = variance); sum of independent Poissons; when Poisson is appropriate.
Select among normal, binomial, Poisson based on context.
Critical values/regions; hypothesis tests:
• Population mean (normal with σ known; t when σ unknown; paired/unpaired).
• Proportion (binomial, one-tailed).
• Mean for Poisson (one-tailed).
• Test ρ = 0 for bivariate normal using technology.
Type I/II errors and their probabilities (normal with known variance, Poisson, binomial).
One-tailed tests only for discrete distributions; critical regions chosen to control Type I error.
Transition matrices and powers; state after n steps s_n = T^n s_0.
Transition diagrams; regular Markov chains; initial state matrices; steady-state/long-term probabilities via repeated multiplication and via eigenvector for eigenvalue 1.

SL.notes: SL5.1–SL5.5 common to AA and AI; (guide continues with SL5.6–SL5.7 optimisation/area concepts in context)

content: Introduction to limits (estimate from tables/graphs; no formal analytic limit techniques).
Derivative as gradient function and rate of change; notation dy/dx, f′(x), etc.; informal gradient as a limit.
Increasing/decreasing functions; graphical interpretation of f′(x) > 0, = 0, < 0; identify intervals of increase/decrease.

AHL.aim: Extend SL differential/integral calculus for modelling/interpretation.

content: Derivatives of sin x, cos x, tan x, e^x, ln x, x^n (n∈ℚ).
Chain, product, quotient rules; related rates; links to maxima/minima and optimisation.
Second derivative d²y/dx² and f″(x); second derivative test; concavity and inflection; links to kinematics and 2nd-order DEs.
Definite/indefinite integrals of x^n (n∈ℚ, including n = −1), sin x, cos x, sec^2 x, e^x.
Integration by inspection/substitution of the form ∫ f(g(x)) g′(x) dx (e.g., ∫sin(2x+5)dx, ∫ dx/(3x+2), ∫ 4x sin(x^2) dx, ∫ (sin x / cos x) dx).
Area under a curve (including negative integrals); volumes of revolution about x- or y-axis: V = ∫_a^b πy^2 dx or ∫_a^b πx^2 dy.
Slope fields (direction fields); read and interpret slope-field diagrams.
Euler’s method for first-order DEs; numerical solutions dy/dx = f(x,y); spreadsheet use; extend to coupled systems dx/dt = f1(x,y,t), dy/dt = f2(x,y,t).
Phase portraits for linear systems dx/dt = ax+by, dy/dt = cx+dy.

Qualitative behaviour for distinct/complex/imaginary eigenvalues; trajectories, equilibria, stability, saddle points; exact solutions required for real-distinct eigenvalues; link to eigenvectors/eigenvalues.
Second-order DEs by Euler’s method via system form.
Investigate d²x/dt² + a dx/dt + b = 0 via phase-portrait ideas; physical interpretations.

internal_assessment.purpose: Apply skills/knowledge to a personally chosen area of mathematics without exam constraints; integrated with normal teaching.
internal_assessment.time_allocation: Recommended ~10–15 hours in total (teacher guidance, class time, consultations, progress review, authenticity checks).
internal_assessment.length_guidance: ≈12–20 pages double-spaced (quality of mathematical writing over length).
internal_assessment.assessment_criteria: Criteria A–E (A–D same for SL and HL; E differs).
internal_assessment.authenticity_guidelines: Must be student’s own work; teacher support limited to advice on one draft; academic honesty and authenticity confirmation required.

papers.type: Compulsory short-response questions; GDC required but not always used; breadth across topics; 110 marks.
Compulsory extended-response questions; GDC required; deeper assessment; 110 marks.

papers.notes: HL investigation paper (details follow in full guide; calculators allowed).
papers.type: Extended problem-solving/investigative tasks aligned with HL content.

general: External papers collectively 80% of final grade.
GDC required for all papers; formula booklet provided.
Marks awarded for method/accuracy/answers/reasoning; show working.
